content: Yes, there are some cultural taboos to be aware of in Pusan and South Korea in general. One of the most important cultural taboos is respect for elders. In Korean culture, elders are highly respected and it is considered rude to speak loudly or interrupt when they are speaking. Additionally, removing your shoes when entering someone's home or certain buildings like temples is a common practice in Korea, so make sure to pay attention to any signs indicating whether to remove your shoes or not. Eating or drinking in public transportation, such as on buses or trains, is also considered impolite. As for clothing, it is advisable to dress modestly and avoid wearing revealing clothing in traditional places like temples. Finally, it is important to use both hands when giving or receiving items, especially money, as it is considered impolite to use only one hand. These are just a few examples of the cultural taboos to be aware of while in Pusan and South Korea.
